content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple fragments of tissue, approximately 6-7 pieces of varying sizes. The overall appearance is consistent with a lymph node dissection specimen, containing potential lymph nodes and surrounding adipose tissue. The largest tissue fragment on the left appears more solid and structured, while other fragments seem more fatty or contain areas of hemorrhage.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this area because it is part of the largest and most well-preserved tissue fragment. In the context of staging colorectal cancer, my primary goal is to identify all lymph nodes and examine them for metastasis. This particular fragment has a distinct, somewhat nodular appearance suggestive of a lymph node, making it a high-priority target for initial examination. I would start here to assess for normal lymphoid architecture or the presence of metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist staging a colorectal cancer case, my primary goal is to find every lymph node in the submitted tissue and examine it for tumor cells. The area indicated by the green box highlights a well-defined, more cellular and structured piece of tissue embedded within the surrounding fat. This is a high-probability candidate for being a lymph node. Therefore, I would zoom into this specific area to confirm its identity as a lymph node and to meticulously screen its architecture for any evidence of metastatic adenocarcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to identify all lymph nodes and examine them for metastasis. I would systematically scan the entire slide and zoom in on every piece of tissue that is not clearly fat. The area in the green box highlights a small, discrete, and relatively basophilic tissue fragment. At low power, its organized appearance distinguishes it from the surrounding hemorrhage and adipose tissue, making it a candidate for being a lymph node. Therefore, it is essential to zoom in to confirm if it is indeed a lymph node and to look for any signs of cancer cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because the green box highlights a small, well-circumscribed, basophilic nodule embedded in adipose tissue. This appearance is highly characteristic of a lymph node. In staging colorectal cancer, it is critical to identify every lymph node and examine it at high magnification to look for metastatic tumor cells. This is a routine part of the systematic search for lymph nodes within the submitted pericolic fat. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The pathologist zoomed into this area because it is a distinct, well-defined, and basophilic (purple) nodule, which is a classic low-power appearance of a lymph node. In cancer staging, it is crucial to examine every potential lymph node meticulously at high magnification to look for metastatic tumor cells. This is part of the routine systematic screening of all tissue on the slide. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in area unexpectedly reveals the characteristic architecture of thyroid tissue. I can clearly identify numerous thyroid follicles of varying sizes, which are spherical structures lined by cuboidal epithelium and filled with pink, homogenous colloid. There is also extensive hemorrhage (large areas of red blood cells) and fibrous connective tissue. This finding is highly unusual for a specimen from a colorectal cancer case. My impression is that this is not a lymph node but rather thyroid gland tissue. This could represent a specimen mix-up or mislabeling, as thyroid tissue would not be expected in a typical colorectal resection. There is no evidence of colorectal adenocarcinoma or lymphoid tissue in this specific field of view.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, the tissue surprisingly does not show the typical architecture of a lymph node or colorectal adenocarcinoma. Instead, it is composed of numerous, well-formed follicular structures of varying sizes. These follicles are lined by a single layer of bland, cuboidal epithelial cells and are filled with a dense, eosinophilic (pink), colloid-like material. This morphology is characteristic of thyroid tissue. There are also some large, congested blood vessels present. My impression is that this is not metastatic colorectal cancer. The findings are pathognomonic for thyroid tissue. This could represent a metastasis from a well-differentiated thyroid carcinoma, or benign ectopic thyroid tissue. Given the clinical context of a colorectal cancer case, this is a highly unusual and discordant finding, and the possibility of a specimen mix-up or a mislabeled slide must be strongly considered.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, the tissue does not appear to be a lymph node. Instead, it is composed of well-defined follicular structures of varying sizes, lined by a single layer of cuboidal epithelial cells and filled with pink, homogenous, acellular material (colloid). This morphology is characteristic of thyroid tissue. There are also large blood vessels, smaller capillaries, and extensive fresh hemorrhage. I do not see any features of colorectal adenocarcinoma metastasis (e.g., atypical glands, necrosis, signet ring cells). The follicular structures themselves appear benign, without significant nuclear atypia, papillae, or mitotic activity. My impression is that this is a fragment of benign thyroid tissue, which is an unexpected finding in a colorectal cancer specimen. This could represent ectopic thyroid tissue or, less likely given the benign appearance, a metastasis from a well-differentiated thyroid carcinoma. It is not a lymph node positive for colorectal cancer.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image shows a portion of a lymph node. There is a thick, pink, fibrous capsule. The internal architecture of the node is largely replaced by dense, pink fibrous tissue and adipose tissue, a process known as fibrofatty replacement or hyalinization. Some dark pigment, likely anthracotic pigment or hemosiderin, is also present. Crucially, in this specific field of view, there are no malignant glands or clusters of atypical epithelial cells to suggest metastasis. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The high-magnification view reveals a surprising finding. Instead of typical lymph node architecture or metastatic adenocarcinoma, the tissue shows numerous well-formed, colloid-filled follicles lined by a single layer of bland cuboidal epithelial cells. This morphology is characteristic of thyroid tissue. This thyroid-like tissue is embedded within a stroma containing aggregates of mature lymphocytes. My impression is benign ectopic thyroid tissue within a lymph node. This is a very unexpected finding in a lymph node from a colorectal cancer case and would raise suspicion of a mislabeled slide or that the specimen is actually from a neck dissection, not a colectomy.
